bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to the Adjutant General, January 12, 1901

div1.p: Gorgas encloses and explains a map of the cases of yellow fever in the City of Havana for the year 1900. Two endorsements are included, January 14 and January 22, 1901. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to the Adjutant General, January 12, 1901
div1.opener:
Headquarters Department of Cuba.
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER OF HAVANA
----------
LA MAESTRANZA
CALLE DE CUBA
ENTRE CUARTELES Y CHACON
-----
Havana, Cuba, January 12, 1901.
To the
Adjutant General,
Department of Cuba,
Havana.
Sir,-
div1.p:
For the information of the Department Commander, I here-
with enclose map of the cases of yellow fever in the City of Havana
for the year 1900.

This map does not include the whole number of cases, as
those occurring in the suburbs Cerro, Vedado, Jesus del Monte, etc.,
are not entered, but it shows those occurring in the settled part of
the City where the very large majority of cases have occurred. The
colored blocks represent the blocks in which cases have occurred. The
numbers in the center of the colored spaces represent the number of
cases that have occurred in these blocks.

As has been the case in most of the years past, the infec-
tion is principally located in the center of the City from Calzada
de Galiano down to the water-front, with San Rafael and Obispo Strees
as the center.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, W. C. Gorgas. Major & Surgeon U.S.A.,
Chief Sanitary Officer.
